title: Inside the Last Neanderthal Stronghold with Prof Alice Roberts | BBC Timestamp
description:
Alice Roberts travels to Gibraltar to explore what may have been the final refuge of the Neanderthals. Evidence from this refuge challenges outdated views of our ancient cousins: far from being primitive, these cave-dwellers show signs of intelligence, adaptability, and cultural complexity, reshaping how we understand their place in human history.  

This clip is from Lost Tribes of Humanity (2016).
 
#AliceRoberts #Archaeology #Neanderthals #Gibraltar

title: Exploring the evolution of walking styles with Prof Alice Roberts | BBC Timestamp
description:
Did you know, the way we use our hands is recorded in our wrist bones? Lucy was part of a species that lived 3.2 million years ago who started walking on two legs instead of living in trees. Let’s take a closer look at the wrist bones of modern humans and chimpanzees, and compare them to those from Lucy’s species,  to find out how and when our ancient ancestors moved from life in the trees to life on the ground.

This clip is from Prehistoric Autopsy (2012).

title: The Forgotten Flight of 1783 | BBC Timestamp
description:
In November 1783, two daring volunteers soared into the sky, becoming the first humans to view Earth from above. Each year, in the French town of Annonay, descendants of the Montgolfier family, renowned paper makers, commemorate this historic leap with a launch of the world’s first hot air balloon, originally crafted from paper.

This clip traces the balloon’s humble beginnings and the fascinating evolution of the power behind human flight.

This clip is from 'The Story of Science: Power, Proof and Passion' (2010)

title: Discovering a 3,500 Year Old Boat in a Kent Underpass | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1992, a wooden boat was discovered buried 20ft beneath an underpass in Dover, Kent. Known as the Dover Boat, dating to around 1,520 BC, it’s the world’s oldest known seagoing vessel. Made of oak planks and yew wood, it carried cargo between Britain and mainland Europe. This well-preserved vessel is currently showcased at the Dover Museum and Bronze Age Boat Gallery.

title: Who Was The Mysterious 'Chariot Queen' That Stunned Archaeologists?  | BBC Timestamp
description:
In April 2001, archaeologists made a discovery in East Yorkshire that stunned experts: an Iron Age female chariot burial, that predated the legendary figure of Boudicca by 300 years.

As archaeologists studied her skull it was clear that she would have been very striking in appearance. Can anthropologist Caroline Wilkinson reconstruct what she may have looked like – and in turn, what might this tell us about her life?

This clip is from Meet The Ancestors: Season 5 (2002).

title: Are you related to a Neanderthal? | BBC Timestamp
description:
Do modern humans have more in common with Neanderthals than we realise?

Anatomist professor Alice Roberts and biologist Dr George McGavin join together with a team of international experts at the Prehistoric Autopsy HQ in Glasgow to reveal the latest research that is casting a new light on Neanderthals, how they might have lived and what we might have inherited from them.

This research was fed to a team of model makers, who then spent months painstakingly reconstructing skeletons, muscles, skin and hair to reveal what our ancient ancestor might just have looked like.

This clip is from Prehistoric Autopsy (2012).

title: Fragile Clues To Identity Of Lost WW1 Soldiers That History Forgot | BBC Timestamp
description:
By the end of 2001, the Diggers had uncovered over 120 sets of human remains from the forgotten WW1 battlefield at Boezinge in Belgium. In their final days on site, more British soldiers emerged from the mud – but who were they? Each fragile clue brings archaeologists closer to uncovering their identities, revealing haunting details of trench life and how they met their fate on the battlefield of Boezinge.

This clip is from Meet the Ancestors: Season 5 (2002)

title: The Biggest Myth Of The Cuban Missile Crisis | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1962, U-2 spy planes captured shocking images of Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba, just 100 miles from US soil, bringing the world to the brink of nuclear war. The official story says President Kennedy stared down Khrushchev and won. But is that the whole truth? Join Lucy Worsley as she uncovers the hidden story of the Cuban Missile Crisis and the most dangerous 13 days in modern history.

This clip is from American History's Biggest Fibs with Lucy Worsley (2019)

title: The 4,000-Year-Old Secret Behind the First Alphabet | Human | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1905, archaeologists at Serabit el-Khadim in Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula uncovered mysterious inscriptions carved into the walls of a 4,000-year-old turquoise mine. The strange symbols, later called Proto-Sinaitic, puzzled scholars for decades, until they realised they were looking at the earliest alphabet in history. But who really gave birth to this simple script that would evolve into the modern alphabets used by billions today?

title: The Mysterious Origins Of The Temple Older Than Stonehenge | Human | BBC Timestamp
description:

Join palaeoanthropologist Ella Al-Shamahi as she uncovers the mysteries of this world’s oldest known temple and reveals the story it tells about humanity’s first steps toward settling down.

title: How Did Early Humans Kill Bears During The Last Ice Age? | Human | BBC Timestamp
description:
14,000 years ago, survival meant risking everything – even facing down a giant bear. In caves along the Canadian coast, archaeologists have theorised how early humans hunted one of the Ice Age’s most terrifying predators: the short-faced bear. But what brutal strategy did they use to take it down? Join palaeoanthropologist Ella Al-Shamahi as she ventures into muddy cave systems in search of ancient bones, stone weapons, and the secrets of a deadly prehistoric hunt.

title: The Architectural Clue That Changed What We Knew About Hampton Court | BBC Timestamp
description:
It's usually thought that Henry VIII built the Great Hall at the heart of Hampton Court Palace. But historian and architectural expert Jonathan Foyle has uncovered a radical theory: that parts of the hall may date back to Cardinal Wolsey, and its layout could reflect Renaissance ideas seen in Italian design. Was Hampton Court a masterpiece of Renaissance architecture before Henry VIII was around?

This clip is from Meet the Ancestors: Season 5 (2002)

title: 20,000-Year-Old Footprints Reveal A Mother's Perilous Journey | Human | BBC Timestamp
description:

Join Ella Al-Shamahi and Professor Matthew Bennet as they retrace the literal steps of one of the first people to walk the Americas – a prehistoric mother on a perilous journey. What can these ancient tracks tell us about life, survival and migration at the end of the last Ice Age?

title: The Forgotten WW1 Battlefield Hidden Beneath Boezinge’s Fields | BBC Timestamp
description:
During the First World War, there were around 750,000 British and Commonwealth casualties in the trenches around Ypres. But the remains of fighting at the small village of Boesinghe (now Boezinge) vanished from history – until the late 1990s, when a group of passionate amateur archaeologists known as the Diggers uncovered its lost WW1 battlefield, rewriting the story of the Great War.

This clip is from Meet the Ancestors: Season 5 (2002)

title: The Hybrid Human Fossils That Shocked Scientists | Human | BBC Timestamp
description:
For decades, experts believed Homo sapiens and Neanderthals never interbred – until a chance discovery in 2002 during a caving expedition at Peştera cu Oase, Romania, changed everything. Join Ella Al-Shamahi as she comes face to face with the remarkable Oase fossils, ancient remains that rewrote human history by revealing a surprising mix of Neanderthal and modern human features.

title: Did Satellite Imaging Reveal A Lost Viking Site In North America? | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 2014, archaeologist Dr Sarah Parcak used cutting-edge satellite technology to hunt for a potential new Viking site along Newfoundland’s coastline. Viking expert Doug Bolender joined Dr Parcak, historian Dan Snow and the team to investigate turf walls and fire‑cracked rocks that they believed could be evidence of Norse activity beyond L’Anse aux Meadows. Could these clues point to only the second known Viking settlement in North America, or will the dating results challenge this theory?

This clip is from The Vikings Uncovered (2016)

title: Archaeologists Stunned By Smallest Human Species Ever Discovered | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 2003, archaeologists excavating Liang Bua cave on Flores Island, Indonesia, uncovered a truly astonishing find: the remains of the smallest human species ever discovered, Homo floresiensis, who lived over 50,000 years ago. Step inside the cave with palaeoanthropologist Ella Al-Shamahi, where history was rewritten, and discover why this tiny species became one of archaeology’s greatest surprises.

title: What History Forgets About Abraham Lincoln's Legacy | BBC Timestamp
description:
President Abraham Lincoln was assassinated on Good Friday, 1865 – instantly casting him as a martyr to the cause of emancipation and the Union. But why did former slaves like Frederick Douglass challenge some of the perceptions of Lincoln that made him a hero? Join Lucy Worsley to uncover the assassination that changed history, the image that shaped his legacy, and the monument that sparked fierce debate across America.

This clip is from American History's Biggest Fibs with Lucy Worsley (2019)

title: What Extinct Human Species Really Looked Like | Human | BBC Timestamp
description:
Long before us, the Earth was home to other incredible human species, including Homo erectus, the mysterious Homo floresiensis, and the often-misunderstood Neanderthals.

We go behind the scenes of new documentary series Human to find out how cutting-edge photogrammetry and CGI was used to reveal surprising truths about how these ancient humans may have looked, lived, why they vanished, and what makes us the last humans standing.

#HumanEvolution #PrehistoricHumans #AncientHumans #Neanderthals #HomoFloresiensis

Human brings our species' untold origin story to life – spanning 300,000 years, at least six human species, and with one extraordinary survivor: us. Presented by Ella Al-Shamahi, Human utilises cutting-edge DNA science, global archaeology, and breathtaking visuals to tell this ambitious story in a totally new way.

title: The Mystery Of 70,000-Year-Old ‘Snake Rock’ Offerings | Human | BBC Timestamp
description:
Long before written history, early humans shaped tools not just for hunting, but for something deeper. At Tsodilo Hills in Botswana, archaeologists uncovered perfectly crafted stone tools from around 70,000 years ago – deliberately burnt, smashed, or left untouched beside a giant snake-shaped rock. But why destroy what took so much effort to create?

title: The Biggest Myth About The American Revolution | BBC Timestamp
description:
Could the United States have won the Revolutionary War without France?

Join Lucy Worsley as she uncovers the forgotten truth behind the 1775–1783 American War of Independence. Far from a solo triumph, the revolution depended on a secret alliance with King Louis XVI of France, who – still bitter over the 1756–1763 Seven Years’ War – saw a chance to weaken Britain and reshape history.

This clip is from American History's Biggest Fibs with Lucy Worsley (2019)

title: Strawberry Hill: The Gothic Masterpiece That Haunted 18th Century Europe | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1747, on the banks of the Thames in Twickenham, Horace Walpole set out to build something extraordinary – a “little Gothic castle” unlike anything seen before. The result was Strawberry Hill, a theatrical masterpiece that would ignite Britain’s Gothic Revival. Discover the eerie origins of 'gloomth', the birth of Gothic fiction, and the strange tale of a tea merchant desperate to step inside this haunting new landmark.

This clip is from Castles: Britain's Fortified History (2014)

title: The Lie That Built America's Most Terrifying Cold War Weapon | BBC Timestamp
description:

But just how far was the Cold War arms race built on a lie?

title: The Dark History Behind Utah's Radioactive Dinosaur Skeletons | BBC Timestamp
description:

But before the boom, this desert was a prehistoric graveyard, where traces of dinosaurs and atomic ambition were buried in the same soil. Its radioactive riches fuelled the nuclear arms race of the Cold War — but at what price?

title: The Chilling Telegram That Ordered the Romanovs’ Execution | BBC Timestamp
description:

description:

title: The Forbidden Royal Wedding Wiped From History | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1785, Prince George – future King George IV – secretly married Maria Fitzherbert, a twice-widowed Catholic. But the marriage was illegal. Why did he hide it from the King and Parliament? Join Lucy
Worsley as she uncovers how this forbidden union nearly triggered a royal crisis that could have changed the course of British history.

title: Was This The Greatest Castle Ever Designed? | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1295, Edward I set out to build his most advanced fortress: Beaumaris Castle, on the island of Anglesey in Wales. Designed by James of St George, it was supposed to be the crowning glory of Edward's so-called 'Iron Ring', yet over 700 years later it remains unfinished. Could this have become the greatest castle ever built, or was it just a vanity project that bankrupted the kingdom?

This clip is from Castles: Britain's Fortified History (2014)

title: The 2,000-Year-Old Machine That Stunned Archaeologists | BBC Timestamp
description:

Michael Wright from Imperial College London reveals how this ancient piece of technology was decoded and what made it such an extraordinary find.

description:
Tutankhamun's iron dagger, buried with the boy king over 3,000 years ago, has long fascinated historians. Was one of history's most famous weapons forged from a meteorite? Physicist Daniela Comelli uses cutting-edge X-ray technology to reveal the truth behind it's mysterious origins.

This clip is from Science's Greatest Mysteries (2022)

title: What History Has Forgotten About Elizabeth I’s ‘Golden Age’ | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1588, Elizabeth I's victory parade masked a harsh truth. England was broke, soldiers were dying of disease, and the queen was fighting to save her reputation. Discover with Lucy Worsley how Elizabeth's 'Golden Age' was built on propaganda and image marketing.

This clip is from Royal History’s Biggest Fibs with Lucy Worsley (2020). Watch on BBC iPlayer: https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/m000fj9f/royal-historys-biggest-fibs-with-lucy-worsley

title: Inside 'Impressive' 5,000-Year-Old Neolithic Tomb  | BBC Timestamp
description:
The West Kennet Long Barrow in the county of Wiltshire isn’t just a burial site – it’s a window into how the Neolithic Revolution transformed beliefs, community life, and our connection with the land. Uncover the secrets of this 5,000-year-old tomb, built by Neolithic farmers around 3600 BC. What mysteries still lie hidden within these ancient stones?

This clip is from A History Of Ancient Britain (2011).

title: Uncovering The Truth Behind Greek Myths | LIVE | BBC Timestamp
description:

title: 'Startling' Discovery Of Tiny Ancient Human Species | BBC Timestamp
description:
On the island of Flores, legends of the Ebu Gogo – small, hairy, human-like creatures – have lasted for generations. But in 2003, archaeologists made a shocking discovery: a tiny human skeleton in Liang Bua cave. Professor Alice Roberts revisits this extraordinary find to investigate what it could mean for our understanding of human evolution.

title: Why You've Been Lied To About Marie Antoinette | BBC Timestamp
description:
Everyone has heard the infamous words Marie Antoinette is supposed to have uttered in response to the starving people of France – ‘Let them eat cake’. It has become one of the most infamous quotes in history. The problem, however, is that it never happened.

In this clip, historian Lucy Worsley explores how and why Marie Antoinette became the scapegoat for the French Revolution.

This clip is from Royal History’s Biggest Fibs with Lucy Worsley (2020). Watch on BBC iPlayer: https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/m000fj9f/royal-historys-biggest-fibs-with-lucy-worsley

title: 8,000-Year-Old ‘Lost World’ Unearthed Beneath The Waves | BBC Timestamp
description:
10,000 years ago, the Isle of Wight didn’t exist – the land stretched to Europe. Now, beneath the Solent’s waves, archaeologists have uncovered what they believe to be one of the oldest boat-building sites in the world. What can these extraordinary finds reveal about how sophisticated the people of the Mesolithic era really were?

title: Prof Alice Roberts Uncovers Incredible Origins Of Ancient Humans | BBC Timestamp
description:
Why did early humans leave their original homeland of Africa, and how did they go on to colonise the world?

From the Ethiopian desert to the Malay peninsula and from the Eurasian Steppe to the Amazon basin, Prof Alice Roberts encounters fascinating archaeological finds that have completely re-written our knowledge of where we came from and deepened our understanding of the challenges that early humans faced as they tried to settle continents.

description:
Was Marie Antoinette truly the architect of France's financial ruin? Once a ruler of extravagance and ambition, Nero’s reign descended into chaos—marked by an attempted assassination, a desperate plan to fund Rome’s grand rebuild, and his ultimate downfall. description:
Professor Alice Roberts meets archaeologist Dr. Mike Collins to discuss a groundbreaking discovery in Texas—evidence that could challenge the timeline of when early humans first came to America. title: The Disastrous 'English Armada' That History Forgot | BBC Timestamp
description:
In 1589, Sir Francis Drake launched a daring counter-attack against the Spanish Armada. But, when the mission ended in failure, this embarrassing chapter of history was slowly erased from the public record. While the defeat of the Spanish Armada is celebrated as a triumph for England, Drake’s failed counter Armada is seldom discussed. Lucy Worsley attempts to uncover the hidden truth behind this disastrous expedition – and why it was conveniently forgotten by history.

This clip is from Royal History’s Biggest Fibs with Lucy Worsley (2020). Watch on BBC iPlayer: https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/m000fj9f/royal-historys-biggest-fibs-with-lucy-worsley

title: Ancient Footprints Reveal ‘Stunning’ Aboriginal Discovery | BBC Timestamp
description:

title: What History Gets Wrong About Anne Boleyn | BBC Timestamp
description:
Anne Boleyn played a pivotal role in shaping English history by pushing King Henry VIII towards the Reformation. While Henry sought the Pope’s approval to divorce Catherine of Aragon, Anne encouraged him to read Obedience of a Christian Man — a controversial book that would influence Henry’s attitude towards the Church. The consequences of Anne’s daring act echoed throughout the Tudor dynasty and reshaped England forever.

title: Why These Advanced Civilisations Collapsed | BBC Timestamp
description:
Explore the catastrophic events that led to the downfall of some of history’s most advanced civilisations. From the volcanic eruption that destroyed the Minoans to the mysterious collapse of the Mayan civilisation, these ancient apocalyptic events have left us with more questions than answers. Now, science is rewriting history, attempting to uncover the truth about these lost civilisations and the cataclysmic events that destroyed them.

title: The Tudor Lie That Rewrote English History | BBC Timestamp
description:
Thomas Cromwell was a master of ambition, strategy, and manipulation. In a time of political turmoil and religious upheaval, he skilfully navigated the storm that was Henry VIII's "Great Matter"—the king’s quest for a divorce from Catherine of Aragon. However, historian Lucy Worsley explores how Cromwell’s aims were not purely to secure the king's desires; they were to advance his own power—and rewrite English history in the process.

title: Incredible Ice Age Cave Paintings Delight Prof Alice Roberts | BBC Timestamp
description:
Prof Alice Roberts visits the Vézère Valley, Dordogne, to discover more about how our ancestors endured the unimaginable conditions of the last Ice Age.

During this time, the Pech Merle cave was used as a place of refuge by prehistoric peoples, as the area had a distinctly arctic, frigid climate, with harsh winters. It is here that Prof Roberts is delighted to view first-hand the magnificent artistic expressions of these early hunter-gatherers.

title: 1,200 Year-Old Ice Reveals Truth Behind Ancient Civilisation’s Collapse | BBC Timestamp
description:
The disappearance of the Mayans has been a topic of contention for centuries. By 950 CE, the Mayan civilisation had collapsed, but no one knows for certain how it happened, or indeed how many people died. Archaeologists have differing theories, including starvation, drought, climate change, disease, and warfare. Now, science can give us extra insight into some of the factors behind their demise. Could 1,200 year old ice hold clues to this ancient mystery?

This clip is from Ancient Apocalypse (2001). Watch on iPlayer in the UK: https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/b01gm6jh/ancient-apocalypse

title: What Happened To The Last Of The Neanderthals? | BBC Timestamp
description:
Thousands of years after Neanderthals had disappeared from the rest of Europe, evidence suggests that they had one final stronghold: Gibraltar. But, as Professor Alice Roberts wonders: being far away from Homo Sapiens, what brought about their end? And did the last Neanderthal really live out their final days here?

title: What Really Happened On Easter Island? | BBC Timestamp
description:
Generations of explorers, archaeologists and scientists have been bewitched by the exotic Easter Island and its mysterious stone statues, and the debate has raged for decades around what might have happened to the people that worshipped them.

Here, studying statues, weapons and human remains, archaeologists attempt to discover what might have happened on Easter Island - and what could have caused the original settlers’ catastrophic end.

This clip is from Horizon: The Mystery of Easter Island (2003).

title: The ‘Science’ Behind the Mona Lisa's Power | BBC Timestamp
description:
The Mona Lisa has gone down in history as one of the most famous and enchanting works of art ever made. Leonardo da Vinci worked on his masterpiece for 16 years, but his desire for perfection meant it remained in his studio even on his deathbed. Though he perhaps still regarded the Mona Lisa as incomplete, the incorporation of science, mechanics and anatomy in his work set a precedent for artists that would last for generations.

title: DNA Reveals Surprising Origins of Mysterious 1,600-Year-Old Skeleton | BBC Timestamp
description:
The discovery of unusually well-preserved 4th Century skeletons in Bath led to a further surprise for archaeologists after DNA testing revealed more about their background and ancestry.

The origins of the male skeleton - found buried, contrary to normal Roman custom, in a lead coffin - gave rise to further questions about his life. Can Julian Richards and his team reconstruct who this person was and how he came to end his life in England at the end of the Roman Empire?

This clip is from Meet The Ancestors (2001).

title: The Truth Behind History's Greatest Legends | BBC Timestamp
description:
Myths and legends are more than mere stories: they serve a profound purpose as sacred tales that explain the world and human experience through the ages. The great legends of King Arthur and the lost city of Atlantis have, respectively, prevailed against the test of time, capturing the imaginations of societies both ancient and modern. But how much historical truth lies behind each of these captivating tales?

description:

title: How Leonardo Da Vinci’s Incredible ‘War Machines’ Ignited His Career
description:
How did Western civilisation’s most beautiful works of art emerge from one of the most brutal periods in history? The Renaissance was a time of betrayal, bloodshed and political upheaval. Yet it was also a time of unparalleled creativity.

For Leonardo Da Vinci, this turbulent era yielded an opportunity. He was hired amidst great turmoil as a secret weapon of war - how, then, did he become known as one of the most influential creative geniuses of his time?

title: 5 Fascinating Archaeological Discoveries From Ancient Egypt | BBC Timestamp

The ancient Egyptians have fascinated us for centuries, and according to one scientist, Dr Sarah Parcak, the astonishing antiquities already discovered are just a tiny percentage of what was left behind.

Here, we unearth some of Ancient Egypt’s greatest mysteries – from the missing tombs of Egypt’s first kings to the hidden secrets of the Great Pyramid of Giza - and see how archaeological discoveries are forcing us to rethink what we thought we knew about this period.

title: Surprising Tools Suggest Neanderthals Were More Advanced Than We Thought | BBC Timestamp
description:
When Homo Sapiens set out from East Africa on a treacherous journey to populate the world, they weren't the only human species on the planet, but they were the only one, ultimately, that would survive. Why is that?

In testing our ancestors’ tools against those of the Neanderthals, Prof Alice Roberts is fascinated to discover that the theory of our superior toolmaking may not be as clear cut as once thought.

title: A Guide To Gladiator Combat | BBC Timestamp
description:
With Ridley Scott’s latest epic Gladiator II hitting cinemas around the world, we have unearthed this gem from our archives. The late great Terry Jones investigates the truth of the Roman Games, uncovering what it took to be a gladiator and the showmanship behind the Games’ violent legacy.

For 750 years, the local colosseum was the prime destination for action and excitement. What began as human sacrifice during funeral rites for wealthy families resulted in a violent, bloody battle staged in front of 50,000 fans. Gladiators were slaves, but the archaeological remains at Pompeii and the Roman Colosseum reveal that they were held in the same esteem as modern day sports stars - a reputation that required a great degree of stylistic ‘panache’ in their fighting.

This clip is from Gladiators: The Brutal Truth (2000).

#Gladiator #AncientRome #Colosseum #Combat

title: Gruesome Murder Souvenirs From ‘Crime of Passion’ | BBC Timestamp
description:
Maria Marten was only 25 years old when she was murdered by her lover, William Corder, in ‘The Red Barn’, Polstead, Suffolk in 1827.

Historian Lucy Worsley explores how this peculiar case ignited profound popular interest: the evil squire and the poor girl, an infamous murder scene, even rumoured supernatural elements. As a result, many morbid relics remain today as a reminder of this notorious murder mystery, each more gruesome than the last.

title: The Disaster That Ended The Minoan Civilisation | BBC Timestamp
description:
The eruption of the Thera volcano, around 1620 BC, is estimated to have been one of the deadliest natural disasters of the ancient world.

Blamed for the collapse of the Minoan civilisation, some historians believe the eruption inspired Plato's descriptions of the sinking of Atlantis. To this day, there is still evidence of the major volcanic activity that changed the dramatic landscapes of what is now present-day Santorini forever.

#History #Volcano #Atlantis

This clip is from the documentary Atlantis: The Evidence.

title: Long-Lost Drawings Found Inside Michelangelo's Secret Bunker | BBC Timestamp
description:
Historian Dr Michael Scott embarks on an adventure to explore the hidden treasures of Italy's astonishing cities, bringing a fascinating new insight into 2,000 years of history.

title: The Hidden History of Italy's Greatest Cities | Italy's Invisible Cities | BBC Timestamp
description:
With the help of cutting-edge 3D scanners, Dr Michael Scott explores the hidden architectural treasures of three Italian Cities. From the beauty and danger of Naples, whose history stretches across 2,500 years, to the glories of Medieval Venice and its incredible engineering, to Florence - the birthplace of the Renaissance - we uncover the real stories of the cities that made Italy and helped shape western civilisation.

The videos in this compilation are from the series Italy’s Invisible Cities.

00:00 - Naples' Underground Tunnels
03:09 - Italy's 'Entrance to the Underworld'
06:33 - Diving to the 'Las Vegas of Ancient Rome'
09:20 - Venice's Incredible Engineering
13:01 - 3D Scans of 14th Century Doge's Palace
16:37 - Casanova's Hidden Casinos in Venice 
19:16 - Inside the Leaning Tower of Pisa
21:25 - Michelangelo's Secret Hiding Place
25:56 - Constructing The Dome of Florence's Cathedral

title: The Deadly Disaster That Ended Egypt’s Ancient Civilisation | BBC Timestamp
description:
Hidden deep in the caves of Israel could be the surprising answer as to why Egypt's Old Kingdom, the civilisation of the great pyramids, collapsed. Dr. Mira Bar Matthews has studied the stalagmites and stalactites and has found she can calculate how much rain fell thousands of years ago. Could an extreme event over 4,200 years ago offer the answer to why such a powerful civilisation disintegrated at the height of its glory?

This clip is from the series Ancient Apocalypse, first broadcast in 2001.
Watch on iPlayer in the UK: https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/b01gm6jh/ancient-apocalypse

title: Discovering The 4,000-Year-Old City Of The Anatolian Kings | BBC Timestamp
description:
The ancient city of Kanesh in Anatolia, which is now a part of modern-day Turkey, was once run by a local dynasty of Anatolian kings and was a major trade hub 4,000 years ago. Many traders paid the kings to provide them protection as they travelled through. The archaeological finds discovered at this site have been hugely significant in understanding the role of trade in the Bronze Age.   

This clip is from the series Ancient Worlds.

#Kanesh #AncientWorlds

title: The Secret Casinos of Casanova's Venice | Italy's Invisible Cities | BBC Timestamp
description:
In between Venice’s scenic canals lie the decadent secrets of the 18th Century. The Venetian casinos were known to house gambling and sex, frequented by legendary figures such as Casanova. With over 10% of Venice’s population at the time being prostitutes, the rooms of these secretive casinos were devoted to ‘pleasures of every kind’ and they went to fascinating lengths to protect the privacy of their customers.

description:

Anthropologist Prof. Alice Roberts speaks to archaeologist Kyle Brown about the ‘vicious’ stone tools found in what may have been one of the world's oldest dwelling.

title: Why Did the Old Kingdom of Egypt Collapse? | Ancient Apocalypse | BBC Timestamp
description:
The Old Kingdom of Egypt (c. 2613–2181 BCE), also known as the 'Age of the Pyramids', was believed to have collapsed due to political conflict. But, with few historical records from the time, Professor Fekri Hassan and other historians have been able to build a greater sense of the period through the hieroglyphics inscribed in tombs. These important inscriptions have allowed us to build a better understanding as to what occurred during this epic period of history.

This clip is from Ancient Apocalypse (2001). This series can be watched in the UK on BBC iPlayer: https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/b01gm6jh/ancient-apocalypse

title: Remains of An Ancient Sun Temple | Egypt's Lost Cities | BBC Timestamp
description:
‘Once, this temple was bustling with people making offerings, and priests performing ceremonies.’

Presenter Dallas Campbell uncovers some of Egypt’s ancient relics, and on this occasion, he's looking at a mighty sun temple. With the sun beating down on the rubble, it's easy to picture what this striking central altar would have looked like, surrounded by offerings to the sun god, Ra.

title: The Mystery of the Italian “Entrance to the Underworld” | Italy's Hidden Cities | BBC Timestamp
description:
In the Bay of Naples, a series of underground tunnels hides a warm river. In Ancient Rome, this was fabled to be the River Styx: an entrance to the underworld. When this river was rediscovered in the 1960s, its secret was revealed – the river was actually heated by geothermal energy. It's easy to imagine why Ancient Romans believed this to be a terrifying way in to the centre of the Earth...

title: Could This Be King Arthur's Birthplace? | BBC Timestamp
description:
The origins of King Arthur are shrouded in mystery and magic. But one myth suggests that Arthur's father, Uther Pendragon, disguised himself as the Duke of Cornwall's husband, to seduce his wife Igraine, with whom he was smitten.

Baby King Arthur was born, and given to the wizard, Merlin, as Merlin had facilitated Uther's wicked disguise. But where did this all take place?

Historian Christopher Snyder goes to a possible location that may be King Arthur’s birth place, discovering something very exciting.

This clip is from the series Arthur: King of the Britons. You can watch this full series in the US and Canada on BBC Select: https://www.bbcselect.com/watch/arthur-king-of-the-britons/
